metadata.title: Complete Academic Expression Database for B2/C1 Writing
metadata.description: Comprehensive collection of academic expressions, verbs, phrases, and discourse markers organized by function, topic, essay type, and sophistication level

cause_effect.title: Cause & Effect
cause_effect.description: Expressions showing causal relationships and consequences

phrases.example: The housing crisis is caused by insufficient construction and rising demand.
phrases.grammarNote: passive voice + by + noun phrase
phrases.usage: Direct causation, most common for B2

phrases.example: The rising crime rate, which is often attributed to unemployment, has sparked debate.
phrases.grammarNote: relative clause + attributed to + noun
phrases.usage: Suggests attribution rather than direct cause

phrases.example: The current economic downturn is a result of poor fiscal policies.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + is a result of + noun

phrases.text: The current crisis is rooted in...
phrases.example: The current environmental crisis is rooted in decades of neglect.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + is rooted in + noun

phrases.text: The underlying cause of the problem is...
phrases.example: The underlying cause of the problem is systemic inequality.
phrases.grammarNote: noun phrase + is + noun

phrases.example: Education is a major factor in the success of any society.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + is a major factor in + noun

phrases.text: The cause is found in our inability to...
phrases.example: The cause is found in our inability to address climate change effectively.
phrases.grammarNote: The cause + is found in + possessive + inability to + verb

phrases.example: Technological advancement has contributed to the development of global communication.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + has contributed to the development of + noun
phrases.usage: Partial causation, one of several factors

phrases.example: This causes considerable delays in public transport.
phrases.grammarNote: This + causes + adjective + noun

phrases.example: The scandal has prompted widespread debate about reform.
phrases.grammarNote: which + has prompted + adjective + noun

phrases.text: The new policy sparked off angry reaction...
phrases.example: The new policy sparked off angry reactions from the public.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + sparked off + adjective + noun

phrases.example: This decision has aroused widespread opposition from environmental groups.
phrases.grammarNote: This + has aroused + adjective + noun

phrases.example: The recession had a devastating impact on the economy.
phrases.grammarNote: a + adjective + impact on + noun

phrases.example: This will partly affect the local industry and employment rates.
phrases.grammarNote: This + will + adverb + affect + noun

advantages_disadvantages.title: Advantages & Disadvantages
advantages_disadvantages.description: Expressions for presenting pros and cons

phrases.example: The key advantages of remote work include flexibility and cost savings.
phrases.grammarNote: The + key/main + advantages/drawbacks

phrases.text: One of the most obvious advantages/disadvantages of...
phrases.example: One of the most obvious advantages of online learning is accessibility.
phrases.grammarNote: One of the most obvious + advantages/disadvantages + of + noun

phrases.text: The essay highlights the potential benefits of...
phrases.example: The essay highlights the potential benefits of renewable energy.
phrases.grammarNote: subject + highlights the potential benefits of + noun

phrases.example: A key advantage of public transport is reduced emissions.
phrases.grammarNote: a key advantage of + noun + is + noun

phrases.text: Perhaps the most striking thing about...
phrases.example: Perhaps the most striking thing about the proposal is its simplicity.
phrases.grammarNote: Perhaps the most striking thing about + noun + is + noun

phrases.example: The potential gains resulting from investment in education are enormous.
phrases.grammarNote: The potential gains resulting from + noun

phrases.example: Its speed is a distinct advantage over traditional methods.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + is a distinct advantage over + noun

phrases.example: The downside of working from home is that it can feel isolating.
phrases.grammarNote: The downside of + noun + is that + clause

phrases.example: The advantages are indisputable and the benefits enormous.
phrases.grammarNote: adjectives for emphasis

opinions.title: Expressing Opinions
opinions.description: Expressions for stating personal views with varying strength

phrases.text: I tend to favour the opinion that...
phrases.example: I tend to favour the opinion that education should be free.
phrases.grammarNote: I tend to favour the opinion that + clause

phrases.example: It appears to me that the situation is improving.
phrases.grammarNote: It appears to me that + clause

phrases.text: It is my considered opinion that...
phrases.example: It is my considered opinion that we need radical change.
phrases.grammarNote: It is my considered opinion that + clause

phrases.example: My personal view of this matter is that we should proceed cautiously.
phrases.grammarNote: My personal view of + noun + is that + clause

phrases.text: My personal judgement on the matter is that...
phrases.example: My personal judgement on the matter is that both sides have merit.
phrases.grammarNote: My personal judgement on the matter is that + clause

phrases.text: I feel/am forced/obliged to conclude that...
phrases.example: I am forced to conclude that the policy has failed.
phrases.grammarNote: I + verb + to conclude that + clause

phrases.text: One is left with no alternative but to conclude that...
phrases.example: One is left with no alternative but to conclude that change is necessary.
phrases.grammarNote: One is left with no alternative but to conclude that + clause

phrases.example: The disadvantages are clearly outweighed by the benefits.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + are clearly outweighed by + noun

problem_solution.title: Problems & Solutions
problem_solution.description: Expressions for describing problems and proposing solutions

phrases.text: The problem constitutes a serious obstacle...
phrases.example: The problem constitutes a serious obstacle to progress.
phrases.grammarNote: The problem + constitutes + a serious obstacle

phrases.text: a need to address the root of the problem
phrases.example: There is a pressing need to address the root of the problem.
phrases.grammarNote: a need to address the root of the problem

phrases.text: The problem seems to be in the fact that...
phrases.example: The problem seems to be in the fact that resources are limited.
phrases.grammarNote: The problem seems to be in the fact that + clause

phrases.text: This is a highly controversial issue...
phrases.example: This is a highly controversial issue that divides opinion.
phrases.grammarNote: This is a highly controversial issue

phrases.example: The issue is highlighted as long as we remain aware of it.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + is highlighted/addressed as long as + clause

phrases.example: We are faced with a crucial dilemma regarding climate policy.
phrases.grammarNote: subject + faced with a crucial dilemma

phrases.example: These challenges present a major obstacle to development.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + present a major obstacle

phrases.example: Funding remains a major stumbling block for the project.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + a major stumbling block

phrases.example: Climate change represents a huge challenge for humanity.
phrases.grammarNote: noun + a huge challenge

phrases.example: We must meet the challenge of sustainable development.
phrases.grammarNote: verb + the challenge of + noun

phrases.example: Crime has become an increasingly vicious concern in urban areas.
phrases.grammarNote: adjective + vicious concern

phrases.text: A number of possible solutions to this problem have been examined...
phrases.example: A number of possible solutions to this problem have been examined by experts.
phrases.grammarNote: A number of possible solutions + have been examined

phrases.text: One of the most effective solutions would be to...
phrases.example: One of the most effective solutions would be to invest in public transport.
phrases.grammarNote: One of the most effective solutions would be to + infinitive

phrases.text: In order to offer the best possible solution/answer...
phrases.example: In order to offer the best possible solution, we must consider all options.
phrases.grammarNote: In order to offer the best possible solution + clause

phrases.text: Another/An alternative that should be pursued is...
phrases.example: Another alternative that should be pursued is renewable energy.
phrases.grammarNote: Another alternative that should be pursued is + noun

phrases.example: Among the solutions suggested is a carbon tax.
phrases.grammarNote: Among the solutions suggested + inversion

phrases.text: Perhaps the most effective solution consists of...
phrases.example: Perhaps the most effective solution consists of education and prevention.
phrases.grammarNote: Perhaps the most effective solution consists of + noun

phrases.text: One way to resolve the situation/difficulty is simply to...
phrases.example: One way to resolve the situation is simply to communicate better.
phrases.grammarNote: One way to resolve + noun + is simply to + infinitive

phrases.text: The need to...must be pointed out...
phrases.example: The need to act urgently must be pointed out.
phrases.grammarNote: The need to + infinitive + must be pointed out

discourse_markers.title: Discourse Markers
discourse_markers.description: Connectives and transitions for structuring arguments

opening.text: Few issues have divided opinion as much as...
Serious concerns are being expressed about...

severity.text: ...continues to escalate at an alarming rate

introducing.text: A viable approach would be to...

results.text: This approach has proven effective in...

strong_agreement.text: Without doubt, I firmly believe that...
I am in complete agreement that...
There can be no doubt that...

partial_agreement.text: While I acknowledge that..., I believe...
To a certain extent, I agree that...
Although there is merit in..., I maintain that...

disagreement.text: I completely disagree with the notion that...
I find this view unconvincing because...
This perspective is fundamentally flawed because...

refuting.text: Yet this argument fails to consider...
On closer inspection, this proves inadequate because...

phrases.text: A prime example of this is...
Numerous cases demonstrate this, such as...

basic_b2.title: Basic B2 Level
basic_b2.description: Simple, clear expressions suitable for B2 entry level

cause_effect_example.basic: Cars cause pollution. This creates health problems.

intermediate_b2.title: Intermediate B2 Level
intermediate_b2.description: More sophisticated structures for solid B2 level

cause_effect_example.intermediate: Vehicle emissions lead to air pollution, which results in respiratory problems.

advanced_c1.title: Advanced C1 Level
advanced_c1.description: Complex, formal expressions for C1 level

cause_effect_example.advanced: Vehicular emissions precipitate atmospheric degradation, thereby engendering acute respiratory complications.

abbreviation_system.title: Abbreviated Note Style for Planning
abbreviation_system.description: Transform formal instructions into authentic student planning notes

examples.formal:

- Give an example: Electric buses and trains in major cities
- Show the result: This reduces emissions significantly
